item.description:
Do you want some flashbacks to the horrors of trigonometry? Here’s fizz buzz in cosines.

I inadvertently picked an area of software engineering that was pretty much exclusively trig and Fourrier transforms. Even back then I really liked formal systems and proofs a lot but for some reason that’s not where I ended up.

https://susam.net/fizz-buzz-with-cosines.html

Good to have explained this explicitly why mathematics is such an essential component of programming. People without an inclination for this kind of abstract mathematical thinking often are poor and chaotic programmers.

https://the-nerve-blog.ghost.io/to-be-a-better-programmer-write-little-proofs-in-your-head

Visual explanations of mathematical concepts are nice if they work. Here’s one such explanation of functional optics which is almost kinda accessible.

https://marcosh.github.io/post/2025/10/07/the-mondrian-introduction-to-functional-optics.html

A very cool and simple introduction into Lean and what makes it interesting. I’m not sure exactly what draws people in this direction but it’s cool to see the progress that’s being made here.

https://overreacted.io/the-math-is-haunted

Solvers are very annoying to setup and plug your problem into if you’re using them regularly. That’s why hooking them into LLMs to do the annoying manipulation work is an amazing idea.

This has the potential to entirely evaporate a vast class of quite complex problems.

https://www.stephendiehl.com/posts/smt_and_mcp_solvers
